In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.    The Pacific developing member countries (DMCs)1 of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  are  among  the  most  vulnerable  nations  threatened  by  climate  change.  The  Pacific 
Islands Forum leaders have long recognized that climate change is a priority development issue, 
and a concerted global effort will have to be taken to halt, or at least slow down, the onset of 
climate change as articulated in the 2008 Niue Declaration on Climate Change. The Pacific 
DMCs have begun to mainstream climate change considerations into their national policies and 
planning processes, and have requested technical and financial assistance from ADB, in the 
course of their consultations during the preparation of the country partnership strategies (CPSs) 
and country operations business plans (COBPs),2 to enable them to take the process further. At 
the  19th  Pacific  DMCs  Governors  Meeting, the  Pacific DMC  governors  requested  ADB  to 
consider establishing a regional climate change fund to support programs and projects aimed at 
strengthening  adaptation  measures  prioritized  by  the  Pacific  DMCs. 3  The  ADB  Pacific 
Department (PARD) has responded positively, with a commitment to provide a broad spectrum 
of  assistance  in  implementing  national  plans  for  climate  change  adaptation  and  mitigation 
through  the  Climate  Change  Implementation  Plan  (CCIP)  for  the  Pacific,4 and  to  work  in 
conjunction  with  other  international  and  intergovernmental  plans  to  tackle  climate  change 
impacts.5 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.6  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Most Pacific DMCs are characterized by their small physical size and geographical 
remoteness, fragile biodiversity, and exposure to natural hazards—making them among the 
most environmentally vulnerable nations in the world. The well-being of the Pacific DMCs is 
threatened by the impacts of climate change. Sea-level rise and extreme climate events are 
already exacerbating inundation, storm surge, erosion, and other coastal hazards, thus putting 
at  risk  vital  infrastructure,  settlements,  and  facilities  that  support  the  livelihood  of  island 
communities. Pacific DMCs lack adequate resilience to absorb the economic shocks attributed 
to  climate  impacts.  Constraints  include  low  human,  financial,  and  technical  capacity;  poor 
coordination between numerous donors operating in the region; and the limited availability of 
scientific information. Already, natural hazards impose significant economic costs on Pacific 
DMC economies. In the 1990s alone, reported natural disasters cost the region $2.8 billion.7  
                                                 
1  The 14 Pacific DMCs are the Cook Islands, the Fiji Islands, Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of 
Micronesia, Nauru, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Timor-Leste, Tonga, Tuvalu, and 
Vanuatu. 
2  The government agencies involved in discussions with ADB on climate change during the CPS and COBP process 
include the finance and environment ministries, climate change focal person and/or institutions, and disaster risk 
management focal point and/or institution, among others. Pacific DMCs have been consulted on the impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, costs, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA.

Global Environment Facility, Japan, New Zealand, United Nations Development Programme, and World Bank, 
among others. 
5  Through ADB support, Palau has already prepared its climate change action plan, and ADB has committed to 
supporting  the  Government  and  other  national  stakeholders  to  develop  a  multilevel  cluster  of  activities  to

2009.

2 
 
3.  Since the granting of the first regional technical assistance (TA) on climate change for 
the Pacific in 2003, ADB is continuing to support the Pacific DMCs through a number of climate 
change initiatives. These include (i) preparation of climate risk profiles, (ii) guidelines for climate 
proofing of infrastructure projects, (iii) assessing feasibility for catastrophe risk financing (jointly 
with  the  World  Bank),  and  (iv)  preparation  of  the  CCIP.8 Enhancement  of  private  sector 
participation in financing adaptation, support for best practice in adaptation at the sectoral level, 
preparation and trial of climate risk reduction tools for screening pipeline projects, and ensuring 
that climate-related risks and vulnerability are adequately reflected in the CPSs of the Pacific 
DMCs are some of the challenges faced by Pacific DMCs, ADB, and development partners. 
Under the ADB work plan and budget framework 2010–2012, many of the projects proposed by 
PARD in the transport and ICT, and energy sectors will require climate-adaptive components 
such  as  climate  proofing  and  provision  for  alternative  freshwater  supply.  Projects  having 
climate-proofing requirements alone will require a low of $86 million and a high of $172 million 
or an average of $130 million during 2010–2012. 
 
4.  Pacific DMCs currently lag the rest of the world in accessing project carbon financing 
through the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM).9 Material transaction costs hinder project 
development, but small-scale methodologies, bundling options, programmatic approaches, and 
grant  financing  largely  mitigate  this  issue.  A  more  significant  barrier  has  been  the  limited 
capacity of national governments and project developers to identify, develop, and manage CDM 
projects. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
5.  The  proposed  regional  capacity  development  TA  will  assist  the  Pacific  DMCs  in 
addressing climate change impacts, as defined by the United Nations Framework Convention 
on  Climate  Change,10 by  building  resilience  through  adaptation  to  climate  change,  climate 
variability, and extreme weather events—taking into account country-specific issues and needs 
at the local level. It will also seek to complement existing climate change activities in the region, 
including the Australian Adaptation to Climate Change Initiative and the Global Environment 
Facility-funded regional Pacific Adaptation to Climate Change project.11 
 
6.  The TA is consistent with the draft Pacific Strategy, 2010–2014,12 which promotes the 
concept of “green growth” in the region in line with ADB’s long-term strategic framework 2008–
2020 (Strategy 2020).13 The TA will support priority climate change-related activities in Pacific 
DMCs identified in the CCIP as well as in ADB CPSs and COBPs,14 building on previous

A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is expected to improve the ability and resilience of the Pacific DMCs to prepare 
for,  and  respond  to,  the  challenges  posed  by  climate  change  impacts  through  the 
implementation  of  priority  adaptation  and  mitigation  measures.  The  TA  will  facilitate  the 
development of adequate climate change adaptation and mitigation plans among the Pacific 
DMCs, and where possible, build on and/or complement existing national adaptation plans of 
action and climate change strategies. It will (i) establish a Pacific climate change program that 
aims to strengthen adaptation (e.g., climate proofing) and mitigation measures (e.g., renewable 
energy development), and develop appropriate financing mechanisms for TA and investments in 
key sectors of Pacific DMCs; and (ii) enhance the Pacific DMCs’ capacity in (a) adopting and 
implementing national climate change adaptation strategy and action plans, and (b) harnessing 
opportunities to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through renewable energy. The outcome of 
the TA will be the incorporation of climate risk management, adaptation practices, and mitigation 
measures into key sectoral investment plans and project designs (e.g., water, transport, energy, 
and agriculture). 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The TA will have three main outputs: (i) the Pacific Climate Change Program (PCCP), 
(ii) adaptation preparation in selected Pacific DMCs, and (iii) the promotion of a mitigation 
strategy in selected Pacific DMCs and identification of mitigation projects for the CDM.  
 
9.  Output  1:  Pacific  Climate  Change  Program. This will set the CCIP in motion by 
assisting  Pacific  DMCs  in  improving  their  resilience  to  climate  change  impacts  through 
(i) mainstreaming  of  the  adaptation  in  their  policies,  plans,  programs,  and  projects;  and 
(ii) strengthening  their  systems  and  capabilities  to  foster  the  adaptation  process,  including 
information and decision support tools, and access to affordable financing of climate-proofed 
development  initiatives.  The  PCCP  will  facilitate  the  systematic  implementation  of  climate-
adaptive investment projects and TA grants as well as climate change mitigation actions in the 
Pacific DMCs. It will render advice and guidance to the Pacific DMCs in the (i) development or 
strengthening of national climate change adaptation and mitigation plans, and (ii) development 
of  capacity  to  access  funds.  These  will  be  done  by  providing,  or  improving  access  to, 
information and knowledge on methodological tools and guidelines for identifying vulnerable 
sectors and population groups; and developing options for adaptation and mitigation, including 
economic costs and benefits analysis.16  
 
10.  It will also develop mechanisms for financing the PCCP. This will include (i) assessing 
financing gaps, and examining grant cofinancing opportunities for TA and investments in key 
sectors covered in the PARD work program and budget framework 2010–2012; (ii) discussions 
and  dialogues  with  development  partners  to  identify  cofinancing  windows,  including  the 
possibility  of  establishing  a  Pacific-tailored  multi-donor  climate  change  financing  facility  for 
mobilizing dedicated resources; (iii) exploring contributions from other development partners 
active in the Pacific region to cofinance projects of common interest within the PCCP; and

11.  Output 2: Adaptation preparation in selected Pacific DMCs. Up to five Pacific DMCs 
will be selected, based on a set of criteria, and supported in preparing the implementation of 
climate change adaptation plans, including further capacity building.18 This will be done initially 
by (i) facilitating the creation or supporting an existing climate change coordinating mechanism 
(e.g., focal point) to assist the Pacific DMCs in building their capacity for adaptation planning at 
national and local levels, and (ii) reinforcing linkages among the many possible adaptation entry 
points to contribute to a more integrated strategy. This output will comprise (i) strengthening 
institutional  capacity  to  prepare  and  assess  climate-oriented  environmental  assessments; 
(ii) development  of  an  information  system  for  multisector  climate  change  vulnerability  and 
adaptation (V&A) assessment;19 (iii) mainstreaming of climate risk management and adaptation 
policies and measures;20 and (iv) design of pilot adaptation projects, based on the prior V&A 
assessment and geographic information system (GIS) mapping, in priority sectors.21  
 
12.  Output 3: Support for Upscaling renewable energy technologies and Capacity 
Building for CDM and Establishment of DNAs. This output will focus on the identification and 
promotion of results-oriented mitigation projects, such as (i) identification of renewable energy 
projects suitable for upscaling, and (ii) support for carbon trading through renewable energy 
projects. It will comprise two sub-outputs: (i) development of renewable energy projects, and (ii) 
support for carbon trading through CDM capacity development. The  TA will promote clean 
energy projects using grid connected hydropower (run-of-the-river), and grid-connected solar 
power, targeting initially two Pacific DMCs - Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) and Republic 
of Marshall Islands (RMI).22 The activities under the TA will include preparation of prefeasibility 
studies, preparation of detailed feasibility studies for selected projects, and development of 
financing proposals.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost the equivalent of $3.815 million, of which (i) $1,775,000 will 
be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV);

needed through a phase 2 TA project.  
18 Selection criteria may include, among others, Pacific DMCs with CPSs or COBPs prioritizing climate change 
interventions. The scope of output 2 may be expanded through channeling of supplementary funds.

21 The priority sectors are (i) natural resources (e.g., coastal and marine resources protection and management,

water supply and sanitation  (e.g., water harvesting techniques, integrated water resource management, urban and 
rural water supply and sanitation, solid waste management); and (iv) energy and transport infrastructure (climate-
proofing). 
22 The scope of support under Output 3 will be expanded through channeling of supplementary funds from the Asian

the target countries (i) are heavily dependent on diesel for power generation, (ii) have policies promoting the use of 
renewable energy, and (iii) have requested ADB assistance for upscaling renewable power generation.

$325,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Canadian Cooperation Fund on Climate 
Change and administered by ADB. The Pacific DMCs will contribute the equivalent of $350,000 
in kind. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  PARD, through the Pacific Operations Division (PAHQ), will serve as the TA Executing 
Agency, and it will establish the PCCP coordination unit comprising core professional staff, 
support staff services and consultants for the coordination, supervision, and implementation of 
all TA activities—with focus on promoting CCIP implementation and establishing linkages with 
the  national  climate  change  focal  points  (NCCFPs)  in  the  individual  countries.  The  PCCP 
coordination unit will also liaise with other relevant ADB units and/or offices, particularly the 
South  Pacific  Subregional  Office  (SPSO),  Pacific  Liaison  and  Coordination  Office  (PLCO), 
Papua  New  Guinea  Resident  Mission  (PNRM),  Special  Office  in  Timor-Leste  (SOTL),  the 
Climate Change Unit and relevant divisions in the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department, Economics and Research Department, and the Office of Cofinancing Operations. 
The TA will be implemented over 2 years from 1 October 2009 to 30 September 2011 in 
collaboration with other programs on climate change in the region. The proceeds of the TA will 
be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.24 Equipment will 
be purchased in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to  time)  and  will  be  handed  over  to  implementing  departments  upon  TA  completion.  The 
progress and outputs of the TA will be shared with the Pacific DMCs and various regional 
development partners and discussed during key regional meetings, such as the Pacific Forum. 
 
15.  The TA will require the services of 48 international and 243 national consultants under 
specific  TA  outputs.  Output  1  consultants  include:  (i)  climate  change  coordinator  and/or 
financing specialist and assistant coordinator, (ii) economist, and (iii) climate change modeler. 
Output 2 consultants are composed of: (i) climate change adaptation specialist, (ii) environment 
and  natural  resources  specialists,  (iii)  infrastructure  specialist,  (iv) GIS  specialist,  (v) 
communication specialist, and (vi) gender specialist. Output 3 consultants include: (i) CDM 
specialist (project manager and deputy project manager), and (ii) renewable energy specialists. 
Output 1 consultants will be recruited on an individual basis, while outputs 2 and 3 consultants 
will be selected through quality- and cost-based selection using a quality–cost ratio of 80:20 for 
evaluating simplified proposals to be requested from short-listed firms.25 Consultant selection 
will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3.  
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
 
16.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $3,140,000 on a grant basis for Strengthening the Capacity of 
Pacific Developing Member Countries to Respond to Climate Change (Phase 1). If the Board 
approves ADB providing the technical assistance, the President, acting under the authority 
delegated by the Board, will approve ADB administering the balance of the technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $325,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Canadian

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE  
 
A.   Introduction 
 
1.   The  regional  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Strengthening  the 
Capacity of Pacific Developing Member Countries (DMCs) to Respond to Climate Change 
(Phase 1) is being proposed as a ground-level link between the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
Pacific  Department  (PARD)  Climate  Change  Implementation  Plan  (CCIP)  and  the  country 
partnership strategies (CPSs) and country operational business plans (COBPs). The TA will 
assist the Pacific DMCs to plan and undertake programs to adapt to the impacts of climate 
change, mitigate the impacts of greenhouse gas emissions, and operationalize the CCIP in the 
Pacific region. The TA will also support the achievement of a number of objectives of the ADB 
CPSs and COBPs in the Pacific region.  
 
2.    The TA will have three main outputs: 
 
(i)  Output 1. Establishment of the Pacific Climate Change Program (PCCP), which 
will include facilitation of the development of national climate change adaptation 
and mitigation strategies, and plans of actions and development of financing 
mechanisms for PCCP projects. A Pacific Regional Economics Climate Change 
Study on the economic cost of climate change in the Pacific will also be prepared. 
 
(ii)    Output 2. Adaptation preparation in five selected Pacific DMCs 
   
(a)  Strengthening  institutional  capacity  to  prepare  and  assess  climate-
oriented environmental assessments.   
(b)  Information  system  for  multisector  climate  change  vulnerability  and 
adaptation assessment. 
(c)  Mainstreaming of climate risk management and adaptation policies and 
measures to support sustainable and resilient economies.  
(d)  Design of pilot adaptation projects. 
 
(iii)   Output 3: Support for Upscaling Renewable Energy Technologies in the Pacific 
and Capacity Building for CDM and the Establishment of DNAs 
 
(a)  Preparation of renewable energy feasibility studies. 
(b)  Improved capacity for implementation of the CDM and establishment of 
designated national authorities (DNAs). 
 
3.   Two sets of consultants will be recruited, both individually and through a firm. The first 
set  of  consultants  will  be  recruited  individually,  either  directly  or  through  a  firm:  (i)  one 
international and one national climate change specialist (coordinator and/or financing specialist 
and  assistant  program  coordinator),  (ii)  one  international  and  one  national  climate  change 
economist, and (iii) one international climate change modeler. The second set of consultants, 
comprising a team of international and national consultants, will be engaged through a firm 
using the quality and cost-based selection method (80:20) and simplified technical proposal 
evaluation according to ADB’s Guidelines for the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from

  1.  Individual Consultants 
 
4.  To manage the activities under outputs 1–3 and to undertake activities in support of 
output 1, two individual consultants will be engaged by ADB. The international consultant—
coordinator and/or financing specialist will provide intermittent inputs equivalent to 15 person-
months, while the national consultant—assistant coordinator will provide full-time inputs over a 
24 person-month period. The two consultants will work closely as a team, and support their 
counterparts in the national climate change focal points (NCCFPs) in the Pacific DMCs to 
ensure that the TA outputs are delivered in an efficient, effective, and timely manner. More 
specifically, they will: 
 
(i)  manage the operations of the PCCP coordination unit within PARD, including the 
coordination and facilitation of financing mechanisms as well as assistance in 
technical, administrative, and finance-related matters; 
(ii)  prepare detailed work and financial plans on an annual basis; 
(iii)  monitor the implementation of the activities under outputs 1–3 of the TA; identify 
bottlenecks,  issues,  and  constraints  to  TA  implementation;  and  recommend 
solutions to identified problems; 
(iv)  assist in the provision of country-level coordination and communication, including 
the promotion of alliances with other development partners; 
(v)  work closely with the national coordination units and NCCFPs in implementation 
of the TA; 
(vi)  provide support in the organization and implementation of regional meetings, 
conferences, and workshops; 
(vii)  assist in setting up the criteria for the selection of countries to participate in the 
piloting of some of the TA activities;  
(viii)  prepare regular progress reports to ADB and the participating Pacific DMCs; and 
(ix)  perform other tasks as may be required from time to time.
